Award.AwardTitle: Research in the Geometry of Minimal and Constant Mean Curvature Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1309236, Principal Investigator: William H. Meeks

The researcher will study the geometry, asymptotic behavior, conformal structure and topology of properly embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space, and more generally, in simply connected homogeneous three-manifolds X. One goal is to classify constant mean curvature spheres in such spaces X and to investigate when they are embedded and if they always represent solutions to isoperimetric problems in X. Another goal of the proposal is to classify the asymptotic behavior of complete embedded constant mean curvature surfaces of finite topology in three-dimensional Euclidean space, and more generally, in homogeneous three-manifolds. Theoretical techniques concerning removable singularities, compactness, regularity and convergence of sequences of embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces will be investigated as well. A final goal is to understand the existence/nonexistence problem for complete, bounded embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces in Euclidean three-space and in other three-dimensional spaces.

Classical minimal and constant mean curvature surface theory has its roots in 18 th and 19 th century mathematics. Minimal surfaces are the first important two-dimensional examples of what is called the calculus of variations, a subject first described by Euler around 1735; constant mean curvature surfaces were first studied by Delaunay in 1835 and they also represent important examples in the calculus of variations. Physically minimal surfaces can be modeled as soap films on wires or by surfaces of least-area relative to their boundaries; physically constant mean curvature surfaces can be modeled as soap films on wires with a constant pressure difference on each side. Minimal surfaces play an important role as a tool in the study of three-dimensional topology and geometry. The research in this proposal concerns global and local properties of embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces and possible applications of these results to basic research in three-dimensional topology and geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Classical minimal and constant mean curvature surface theory has its roots in18-th and19-th century mathematics. Minimal surfaces are the first important two-dimensional examples of what is called the calculus of variations, a subject first described by Euler around 1735; constant mean curvature surfaces were first studied by Delaunay in 1835 and they also represent important examples in the calculus of variations.  In the previous year, the PI and G. Tinaglia were able prove the famous conjecutre that round spheres are the only complete simply connected non-zero constant mean curvature surfaces embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space and that the only complete embedded non-zero constant mean curvature annular examples are the classical Delaunay exmaples.  

Physically minimal surfaces can be modeled  as soap films on wires or by surfaces of least-area relative to their boundaries; physically constant mean curvature  surfaces can be modeled  as soap films on wires with a constant pressure difference on each side.  Minimal surfaces play an important role as a tool in the study of three-dimensional topology and Riemannian geometry.  The research in this proposal concerned global and local properties of embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces and possible applications of these results to basic research in three-dimensional topology and geometry.

The PI also studied the geometry, asymptotic behavior, conformal structure and topology of properly embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space, and more generally, in simply connected homogeneous three-manifolds X. One goal was to classify constant mean curvature spheres in such spaces X and to investigate when they are embedded and if they always represent solutions to isoperimetric problems in X. Togeher with Mira, Perez and Ros the PI was able to carry out this classification, and they are presently writing up this important  classification result. Another  goal of the proposal was to classify the asymptotic behavior of complete embedded constant mean curvature surfaces of finite topology in three-dimensional Euclidean space, and more generally, in homogeneous three-manifolds. The PI studied theoretical techniques concerning removable singularities, compactness, regularity and convergence of sequences of embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces was investigated as well.  A final  goal was to understand the existence/nonexistence problem for complete, bounded  embedded minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces in Euclidean three-space and in other three-dimensional spaces. Perhaps the best result proved by the PI along these lines was the solution to an old conjecture that asked if the classical embedded minimal planar domains discovered by Rieman in 1860 (these examples are foliated by circles and straight lines) are the only properly embedded minimal planar domains in space with infinite topology;  the PI together with Perez and Ros proved this conjecture and published their proof in 2015 in the Annals of Matheamtics. 

The subject of minimal and constant mean curvaturesurfaces has a broad impact in mathematics and in the physical sciences.Minimal surfaces represent stationary fluid interfaces, and so theirshapes arise in many physical problems.  The work in this proposalwill help classify the possible physical shapes which could occur asinfinite interfaces.  Many of the known examples of minimal and constant mean curvature surfacesare observed physically, and so it is of interest to have a rigorous theory which predicts the shapes which can occur. The research proposed strongly impacts the area of classical differential geometry of surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space.  As is well known to geometers, minimal surface theory has been and continues to be one of the principal tools for proving theorems ingeneral relativity and three-dimensional topology.   In part because of the important connections with other areas of mathematics and the ease in which it is possible to make computer graphics pictures of beautiful classical examples, minimal and constant mean curvature surfaces continue to be one of the principal topics for popularscience articles and public science exhibits.  Thus, indirectly, the exciting research problems studied in this proposal helped bring many young scientists and mathematicians to the frontiers of research.
